translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 14
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Part Two of the Path
I have already explained the path, removed the thorns of craving, you should encourage yourselves,
and accept the words of the TathÄgata.

The teachings of the TathÄgata will never be repeated, his words become teachings and are never repeated, what he says is always gentle and never abrupt, the fundamental Dharma he expounds accords with the meaning, observing those who receive the teachings, he asks what Dharma they should be liberated by and immediately goes to liberate them, what has been said and what will be said are presented according to the time.
Therefore it is said, I have already explained the path.

Removing the thorns of craving means that craving is a disease that causes one to fall into evil destinies and cannot be relied upon. Within this, one should pull oneself out and control with stillness and contemplation, not giving rise to a mind of craving. It is like a poisonous arrow that enters a person's chest and cannot be pulled out. This arrow of craving is also like this, entering a person's consciousness and cannot be pulled out. Therefore it is said, removing the thorns of craving.

You should encourage yourselves means always thinking of diligently seeking skillful means, aspiring for the unsurpassed and never regretting it in the middle, and also not turning back. Therefore, it is said, You should encourage yourselves.

Accept the TathÄgata's words means the teachings expounded by the TathÄgata who appears in the world, with good meaning and principle in the beginning, middle, and end, replete with myriad virtues, and able to cultivate the pure life. Therefore, it is said, Accept the TathÄgata's words.
This path has no remainder, purified by seeing the truth,
Aimed at ending all suffering, it can destroy the army of MÄra.

This path has no remainder means the Chang Ahan Jing Sutra speaks of the seven buddhas, tathÄgatas, and samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas, and also speaks of the seven generations of parents, their clan names, lifespans, retinues, spiritual powers, wisdom, and posthumous children. VipaÅ›yin TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha appeared in the world when the human lifespan was 80,000 years, born into the brahmin caste;
To summarize, the attendant was named Sorrowless. When gathering to recite the precepts, patience was considered the foremost. The details are as explained in the sutras.
When the Tathagata, Arhat, Samyaksambuddha Shiqi appeared in the world, he was born into a Brahmin family, and the human lifespan was 70,000 years.

To summarize the essentials, the attendant was named Auspicious Conduct. When gathering to recite the precepts, the eyes should not look at what is improper. The details are as explained in the sutras.
When the Tathagata, Arhat, Samyaksambuddha Vishvabhu appeared in the world, the human lifespan was 60,000 years, and he was born into a Kshatriya family.
To summarize the essentials, the attendant was named Rest. When gathering to recite the precepts, one should neither harm nor kill. The details are as explained in the sutras.

When the Tathagata, Arhat, Samyaksambuddha Krakucchanda appeared in the world, the human lifespan was 50,000 years, and he was born into a Brahmin family. The attendant was named Buddha-ti. When gathering to recite the precepts, it was said that one should be like a bee collecting nectar from flowers. The details are as explained in the sutras.
When the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One Kanakamuni appeared in the world, the human lifespan was forty thousand years, and he was born into the ká¹£atriya caste;
To summarize the essentials, his attendant was named Jiji, and when he gathered to recite the precepts, he also did not disturb him, as explained in detail in the sÅ«tras.
When the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One KÄÅ›yapa appeared in the world, the human lifespan was twenty thousand years, and he was born into the brahmin caste;
To summarize the essentials, his attendant was named Dá¹›á¸ha, and when he gathered to recite the precepts, he said, Do not do any evil, as explained in detail in the sÅ«tras.
As for myself today, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One ÅšÄkyamuni, when he appeared in the world, the human lifespan was one hundred years, and he was born into the ká¹£atriya caste;
To summarize the essentials, his attendant was named Ä€nanda, and when he gathered to recite the precepts, he said, Protecting the speech is the foremost, as explained in detail in the sÅ«tras.

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke of the origins of the Seven Buddhas, the parents of the seven generations, their names, surnames, and the number of their followers, and explained the precepts from beginning to end.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us, having heard what the Buddha said, each gave rise to this thought:

The surnames, names, and numbers of disciples of the Buddhas of the past were each different, and the prohibitions of the Way they practiced also had distinctions. Since the Way is not the same, the Dharma should also be different.
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, knew what the bhiká¹£us were thinking in their minds, and then spoke this verse to the assembly:
This Way has no other, it is purified by seeing the truth,
It leads to the cessation of all suffering, it can destroy the army of MÄra.

The Buddhas of the past, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, also awakened to this path by themselves. Leading their followers, they destroyed the aggregates of existence, raised the banner of liberation, and beat the great Dharma drum. They ended birth and death, established the practice of purity, accomplished what was to be done, and no longer accepted existence, knowing it as it truly is.

They have entered the realm of sorrowlessness, and are no longer subject to birth, old age, sickness, or death. They are peacefully in nirvana, without arising or ceasing, and without going or coming.
Therefore it is said, This path is unsurpassed, purified by seeing the truth.

Approaching the cessation of all suffering means approaching the attainment of the fruit of once-returning and attaining the fruit of once-returning, approaching the attainment of the fruit of non-returning and attaining the fruit of non-returning. Straightforward practice is accomplished, the practice of awakening is accomplished, and equal karma is accomplished. The mind is not inverted and gradually reaches the path.
Therefore it is said, Approaching the cessation of all suffering.
This can destroy the army of Mara - what are the bonds of Mara?

Those who are attached to the defilements of the desire realm seek an opportunity to permanently cut them off without remainder, to extinguish the heavy, to destroy the heavy, to exhaust the heavy, to beat the heavy, to peel the heavy, to cross the demon's boundary and enter the form and formless realms. Therefore, it is said that this can destroy the demon's army.
This is truly unsurpassed, the sole path like a flowing stream,
Like the Able and Benevolent One entering concentration, expounding the Way to the assembly.

This is truly unsurpassed means going straight to the unconditioned, directly to nirvana, crossing over the midst of birth and death without retreating, staying on the shore of birth and death, looking back at sentient beings, wishing to return together, having already reached the other shore, never turning back again. Therefore, it is said that this is truly unsurpassed.

The sole path like a flowing stream is like a clear and still spring, deep and pure, able to satisfy the hunger and thirst of billions and trillions of sentient beings, without any thought of hunger or thirst, nourishing them with the flavor of the Dharma, removing their afflictions.

It is the same here. Relying on the noble path, billions and millions of beings who are hungry and thirsty for the path are satisfied with the sweet nectar of the Dharma, forever free from thoughts of hunger and thirst, and their afflictions are eliminated without any distress. Unwholesome actions are removed and never arise again.
Therefore, it is said: The one path is like a flowing stream.
As for like the one who can enter concentration, Shakyamuni Buddha, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Fully Enlightened One, focuses his mind and enters concentration for four reasons.
What are the four?

First, he delights in the present Dharma himself; second, he enjoys the Dharma offerings; third, he stabilizes his concentration without disturbance in order to support the weak and save the feeble; fourth, he encourages progress to reach the ultimate.
Therefore, it is said: Like the one who can enter concentration.

To expound the Way to the multitude means to enable disciples to not err in the multitude, to rescue them from birth and death and settle them in the unconditioned, to bathe them in purity and not be tainted by dust and defilements, to permanently leave cyclic existence and not give rise to the eight dharmas, and also not create the four hundred and four diseases. Therefore, it is said, to expound the Way to the multitude.
One entry sees birth and death, the Way is to obtain assistance,
This Way crosses over those to be crossed over, cutting through the flow to reach the other shore.
One entry sees birth and death - who can awaken to the original source of birth and death?

The World-Honored One VipaÅ›yin, while originally practicing the bodhisattva path, was able to awaken to the original source of birth and death, and later expounded the subtle Dharma to his disciples.
Who can discern defiled dharmas?
There is only the one entry into the Way that can awaken to it.
Therefore, it is said, one entry sees birth and death.

As for the path being for attaining assistance, when bodhisattvas are in the assembly they give rise to great compassion, they pity all sentient beings as a mother loves her child, they expound the profound path, enabling them to attain liberation. Therefore, it is said, the path is for attaining assistance.

As for this path crossing over those to be crossed over, in the past world, Buddhas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas all used this path to cross over the ocean of desire. Therefore, it is said, the path is for attaining assistance.

As for this path crossing over those to be crossed over, in the future, all Buddhas, World-Honored Ones, like Maitreya and others, will cross over innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of sentient beings. Therefore, it is said, this path crosses over those to be crossed over.

As for cutting off the flow and reaching the other shore, the present Buddha Shakyamuni, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, has crossed over innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of sentient beings. Therefore, it is said, cutting off the flow and reaching the other shore.
The ultimate path is pure, having exhausted the basis of birth and death,
Innumerable eloquence, the Buddha says this is attaining the Way.
As for the ultimate purity of the path, the ultimate has two meanings:
First, it is called the ultimate of affairs; second, it is called the ultimate of concentration.
As for the ultimate of affairs, the affairs one does are accomplished and certain, without doubt.

As for the ultimate of concentration, one plays with various concentrations, rising from one concentration and entering another concentration, thus going through countless thousands and millions of concentrations. If one wishes to move something, it is accomplished according to one's wish. This is called the ultimate of concentration.
Using this right practice, one removes the dharmas contemplated by the mind, cuts off the afflictions, and attains purity, just as dusty clothes are washed to be made pure.
This is also like this. With the pure water of the eight liberations, one bathes the defilements of the mind and is forever free from dust and obscurations.
Therefore, it is said: the ultimate purity of the path.

To end the root of birth and death means that all beings who have the factor of birth will inevitably age and die. It is also due to birth that sentient beings transmigrate and return to the five realms. It is also due to the shifting and unceasing consciousness that one speaks of ending the root of birth and death.

Eloquence in countless realms means that the TathÄgata's spiritual virtues adapt to the situation and transform without bounds. With the wisdom of eloquence, he roams in countless realms, observing sentient beings, some with sharp faculties and some with dull faculties, some false and some true, some practicing the true path and some not practicing the true path. The TathÄgata knows all of this.
Therefore, it is said, Eloquence in countless realms.
The Buddha speaks of attaining the Way - the word world has three meanings:
First, the world of aggregates; second, the world of vessels; third, the world of sentient beings.
The world of aggregates refers to the five aggregates;
The world of vessels refers to the trichiliocosm;
Sentient beings and the world refers to all kinds of beings up to the four kinds of birth, all of which are called sentient beings and the world.
Who can discern and understand this birth?
The answer is:
Only the Tathagata, the Arhat, can know it.
It is just like a person with eyes looking at an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of their hand, they can fully understand its size and weight.
The TathÄgata's perfect enlightenment is also like this, observing the fundamental mind and thoughts of sentient beings, he can fully discern them.
Therefore it is said, the Buddha explains the attainment of the Way.
The swift current pours into the ocean, the water in the basin envies its rapid filling,

Therefore, for the sake of the path of wisdom, it is said that one can enter and taste the sweet dew.ğŸ”½The swift current pours into the ocean refers to a great river called the Ganges, which flows out from the Anavatapta Spring, flowing from the mouth of a cow;
The new head river also flows from the Anavatapta Spring, flowing out from the mouth of a lion;
The great river Vakhsh also flows out from the mouth of a horse in Lake Anavatapta;
The great river SÄ«tÄ also flows out from Lake Anavatapta, from the mouth of an elephant.
As for the Ganges River, it is revered by Brahmins as their teacher. Non-Buddhist practitioners say to each other:

If there are learners who go beyond a hundred yojanas from the Ganges River and chant the name of the Ganges three times from afar, 'Ganges, Ganges, Ganges,' although they stay a hundred yojanas away, all their various evils are eliminated, like a snake shedding its old skin. The waters of the Ganges all return to the ocean, clear and pure without any impurities.
Therefore it is said, The swift current pours into the ocean.

As for the current of the river is swift and full, flowing into the ocean day and night without stopping, from the ocean it returns to the mountain of burning charcoal, from the mountain of burning charcoal it returns to the root of the snow mountain, in this way gradually returning to the original source, flowing day and night, going around and starting over again, the ocean is also not full and the current does not stop, therefore it is said, the current of the river is swift and full.

Therefore it is said, the wise one shows the path. The buddhas, the world-honored ones, are all called the well-gone, having reached the place of nirvana's extinction, having already attained to it, there is no birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, worry, suffering, or distress, and there is also no hunger, cold, or hardship, completely free from this suffering, therefore it is said, the well-gone.
Therefore it is said, the wise one shows the path.
As for one can go and taste the nectar, one can go and reach the realm of nirvana, seeking the nectar, just as all the rushing rivers are called the ocean, fully accomplishing the deeds of the ocean.
This noble Dharma and Vinaya is also like this. Gradually, one can reach the realm of nirvana. Therefore, it is said, One can approach and taste the nectar.
The Dharma wheel that had not been turned before, was turned for the sake of sentient beings.
Those who revere and serve it, pay homage to it and transcend the three realms of existence.
Formerly, the Buddha was in the Deer Park of the Sage in the country of Varanasi. The river was called Vapi, and because of that, it was called the country of Varanasi.
As for the Deer Park of the Sage, all sages who attained the Way and had the five supernatural powers studied there. It was a country inhabited by only virtuous people, not ordinary people.

At that time, the king of that country went out to hunt in the wild. He encountered a herd of a thousand deer that all entered a net. The king deployed infantry to surround them in a circle. The herd of deer was frightened and some cried out and bumped into the traps, while some lay down and hid themselves.
When ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha was a bodhisattva in the past, he was born among a herd of deer and was the leader of the herd. He told the herd of deer:
You should be at ease and not be afraid. I will devise a means to beg for mercy from the king, and we will surely be able to save our lives and each be safe.
At that time, the king of the deer immediately knelt before the human king and begged for mercy. The king saw him from afar and ordered his attendants not to raise their hands to harm the deer.
The deer then raised its voice and knelt towards the king, saying:

Now, I observe that the king intends to kill a thousand deer in one day to supply the kitchen. Now, it is hot and the meat cannot last long. I beg the king to have mercy and kill one deer a day to supply the kitchen. It will not trouble the king. The deer will go to the kitchen to accept death on its own, and the supply of meat will not be cut off, and the deer will increase in number.
The king asked the deer:
Are you the largest among the herd of deer?
It replied:
Yes, it is so.
I am the largest.
The king asked the deer again:
Are you really sure?
He replied:
I am really sure.
The king then released the deer, withdrew his troops, and entered the city.
At that time, the Bodhisattva led five hundred deer, and Devadatta also led five hundred deer. Each day, one deer was sent to the king's kitchen.
At that time, it was Devadatta's turn to send a deer to the king. A pregnant doe, due to give birth in a few months, was next in line for the kitchen.
The doe went to the king and pleaded pitifully:

I dare not refuse to go to the kitchen when it is my turn. But now I am about to give birth and will share my body with my child. My turn has come, but my child's turn has not yet come. I wish to be excused and allowed to go later.
Devadatta became angry and said:
Why don't you go quickly?
Who can take your place and die first?
The doe wept sadly and cried out, then went to the Bodhisattva and pleaded:
The day of my delivery is approaching, I wish the king would show mercy and allow me to take my turn later, after giving birth to my young, then I will go to the kitchen.
The Bodhisattva asked the deer:
Did your master give you permission to speak like this?
He replied:
The master did not give permission.
When the Bodhisattva heard this, he sighed eight or nine times and comforted the deer:
You should be at ease and not be afraid. I will now take your place to be slaughtered in the kitchen.
The Bodhisattva Deer King then summoned the thousand deer and earnestly instructed them:
You should each not be lazy, and do not encroach on the king's autumn crops to eat.
Devadatta heard this and became angry with the doe:
Your death is imminent, why do you plead for a delay in dying?
At that time, the Bodhisattva immediately said to Devadatta:
Stop, stop! Do not speak these words!
The doe is indeed due to die next, but it is out of pity for the unborn fetus that should not die.
I will now take their place and save the lives of those in the womb.
As the Bodhisattva was thinking this, the herd of deer knelt before him and each spoke out, saying:
We wish to take the king's place and die. While we are alive, the king can eat the water and grass as he pleases, roaming freely without any fear or concern.
The king's intentions were strong, so he let them go and went to the kitchen. The herd of deer chased after him and followed him to the king's palace.
The king of the deer went to the kitchen himself to seek his own slaughter. The kitchen staff saw the king of the deer and clearly recognized him. They immediately went to report to the king:
The king of the deer has entered the kitchen and is next in line for slaughter. I do not know if the great king will allow him to be killed.
When the king heard this, he threw himself under the bed. The ministers sprinkled water on him and helped him back to his seat. The king ordered the ministers:
Quickly bring the king of the deer here. I wish to see him.
They soon brought him to the king. The king asked the deer:
Are the thousand deer all gone?
Why have you come?
The deer said to the king:ğŸ”½Great king, listen!
The thousand deer gave birth to fawns, and eventually formed a large herd, increasing day by day without decrease.
He then told the human king the origin of the deer.
The king blamed himself and lamented his own inadequacy:
I am the king of men, yet I cannot distinguish true from false and unjustly kill living creatures, to the point of this.
The king told his ministers:
Order the entire country that anyone who hunts and kills deer will be executed.
He then sent the king of deer to lead the herd of deer back to the mountains to settle, and ordered the country not to eat deer meat. Anyone who ate deer meat would have their head cut off.
Because of this, it was named the Deer Park.
At that time, the World-Honored One was in the Deer Park turning the wheel of the Dharma. Therefore it is said, The wheel of the Dharma that had not been heard before.

Turning the wheel for the sake of sentient beings means that he first spoke the Dharma to the five people and to the eighty thousand celestial beings, repeatedly explaining the true suchness of the four truths, which had never been heard or seen before, and which could not be turned by Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmans, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, the various gods, MÄra, or MÄra's celestial beings. Therefore, it is said, Turning the wheel for the sake of sentient beings.

Herein, those who revere and serve him are seen and respected by the celestial beings and people of the world. Abiding in the land of JambudvÄ«pa, he spreads and teaches, and those from the six heavens below are all liberated and saved.
Question:
Why does he only speak the Dharma to celestial beings and people, and not to others?
Answer:
Celestial beings and people can attain the fruit of the path and realize it out of order, and the multitude knows their mastery.
Excluding the method of the eight precepts, excluding the three refuges of ghosts and spirits.
It is like the diligent and pure practice of the animal KapiÃ±jala bird.
In the past, there were three animals living in a deep mountain: an elephant, a monkey, and a kapiÃ±jala bird.
The elephant said to the two animals:
The three of us do not respect each other and have no etiquette. Now we should push and yield, who should be the elder and be the leader?
At that time, there was a large tree that was tall and wide, shading five hundred carts. The monkey introduced himself:
I used to eat its sprouts.
The elephant said:
I ate its tree.
The monkey said:
You should push me as the elder.
The elephant then lifted the monkey onto its back. The kapiÃ±jala bird also introduced itself, saying:
I used to roam north of the Himalayas and eat sweet fruits. I defecated here, and this tree grew. I should be the elder and be the leader.

The monkey carried them on its back, going from country to country, from village to village, fasting and observing the precepts, respecting each other, and if they obtained food and drink, they pushed it to the elders.
The people in the cities and villages who saw this were amazed and had never seen anything like it. They gathered from all four directions and asked about the reason.
The three beasts explained what they had experienced in the past. Although the elephant was large in form and young, it was small, respecting the two beasts above it as a child serves its father.
The people were moved by the beasts and each gave rise to a good mind:
Even birds and beasts are like this, how much more so for us humans?

They encouraged each other and served each other above and below. The people of the whole country who were filial and respectful were numerous. They could have this meaning of filial obedience, but they were unable to transcend the sequence and attain the fruit of the Way. Only the heavenly beings were most worthy of reverence.
Therefore it is said, In serving them.

Paying homage to those who have crossed the three realms of existence means to respect sentient beings, seeing the form of the Tathagata everywhere, serving and paying homage to him, turning away from him for a long time and then turning the mind back without leaving the Buddha.
The three realms of existence are the realm of desire, the realm of form, and the formless realm.
Who can cross these three realms of existence?
Only the World-Honored Buddha can cross them.
Next, there are disciples of the Buddha who, by inheriting the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, can cross the three realms of existence.
Therefore, it is said, Paying homage to those who have crossed the three realms of existence.
The three thoughts should think of good, the three thoughts should avoid evil,
From thought there is action, extinguishing it is right elimination.

The three thoughts should think of good means to think of food and rest according to the time without neglecting, always thinking of good and possessing the roots of many virtues, gradually attaining the stages and receiving various fruits and evidence, ending the source of birth and death, ending the contaminated and accomplishing the uncontaminated. Therefore, it is said, The three thoughts should think of good.
Third, the thought of leaving evil - having already left evil thoughts, what merits are obtained?
The answer is:
Not being defiled by the stains of the mind, removing the stains of the various bonds and attachments, and also not being controlled by those bonds.
Therefore, it is said, The third thought is to leave evil.

From thought, there is practice - having perception and contemplation, playing in the first dhyÄna, up to the fourth dhyÄna, removing the evil and unwholesome thoughts, daily progressing in the practice and never retreating, therefore it is said, From thought, there is practice.
Destroying it is right elimination - using the wisdom of elimination, using this to destroy it.
What is meant by elimination?

Either for confused thoughts, suppressing the wholesome mind, not following the practice of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, covering up the various fruits of the path and not allowing them to appear.

Just as suddenly a storm arises, covering up the sun and moon and not seeing their bright light, when the dragon brings down sweet rain in a timely manner, it covers up the dust and then sees the sun and moon shining brightly.

It is the same here. Using the sweet dew of the sages to extinguish the dust and defilements of the mind, one suddenly greatly awakens without any remaining subtle obscurations. The fruits of the sages' path are all revealed.
Therefore, it is said that cessation is right exertion.
The three contemplations are the turning of the mind, attaining the unsurpassed path,
Attaining the three, eliminating the three abodes, cultivating immeasurable mindfulness.
The three contemplations are the turning of the mind. In the past, the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park in the country of Shravasti.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhikshus:
In the past, before I attained the path of Buddhahood, I gave rise to three kinds of unwholesome thoughts: thoughts of desire, thoughts of anger, and thoughts of harm.
He asked:
At that time, how did the Bodhisattva give rise to thoughts of desire, anger, and harm?
He replied:

The Bodhisattva practiced austerities for six years, and after rising from suffering, he recalled the past and pursued the singing, laughter, music, and entertainment he had experienced in the past, and thus gave rise to thoughts of desire.
He also heard Devadatta secretly harboring thoughts of usurping the palace women and concubines, and at that time he gave rise to thoughts of anger.
The two defilements mixed together, and in the midst of this he gave rise to thoughts of harm.

Furthermore, after the Bodhisattva rose from his ascetic practices, the two women Nanda and Nandabala anointed the Bodhisattva's body with ghee and sesame oil. The bodies of those women were extremely soft and delicate, like celestial maidens, and he gave rise to thoughts of desire and love for them.
At that time, the Bodhisattva thought:
'If those five people who served me had not abandoned me and left, how could these women have anointed my body with oil?'
At that time, the Bodhisattva gave rise to thoughts of anger and also thoughts of harm. The two defilements mixed together, and in the midst of this he gave rise to thoughts of harm.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought like this:
I have now given rise to thoughts of desire, harming myself and also harming others, both things are harmful.
As for harming oneself, all wholesome merits are abandoned and leave, this is called harming oneself.
How does one harm others?

If one eats the offerings of faith from others, such as clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine for illness, and is unable to digest them, one will only increase afflictions and not attain the fruits and virtues, this is called harming others.
To put it simply, when the two defilements come together, thoughts of harm arise.

At that time, the Bodhisattva was disgusted with these two things and sought to extinguish unwholesome thoughts. With the power of patience, he subdued the demon Mara and his troops, forever abandoning chaotic thoughts and not giving rise to evil thoughts, quickly accomplishing the fruits of the Way.
Therefore, it is said: the three contemplations turn the mind.
Attaining the unsurpassed Way - what is the unsurpassed Way?
As for the so-called unsurpassed Way, the answer is:
Aspiring to seek liberation, without thoughts of desire or anger.
Therefore, it is said that the three contemplations are for turning the mind.
Attaining the unsurpassed path means that the Bodhisattva, sitting under the Bodhi tree, abandoning thirty-four thoughts, attains the unsurpassed path.
What is called the unsurpassed path surpasses the heavens and humans of the world, and the insects and worms of the trichiliocosm, it is the highest and none can surpass it.

As explained in the sutra, seven atoms make one louse egg. What is called an atom is neither long nor short, neither round nor square, neither high nor low, it has no form and cannot be seen, it is not within the scope of visual consciousness.

The reason for this is that because it is extremely subtle, it cannot be seen. Only the wheel-turning sage king, the bodhisattva who is about to attain Buddhahood, and those with the divine eye of the sages can see it.
Even if there were a dharma that surpasses this extreme subtlety, the TathÄgata would penetrate it, awaken to it, and know it.
Therefore, it is said, Attaining the unsurpassed path.

Attaining the three, eliminating the three abodes means abiding in the four dhyÄnas, entering pure concentration, not giving rise to attachment, quickly extinguishing afflictions, focusing the mind without forgetting, diligently cultivating without slacking off, roaming in the three and four, concentrating on eliminating bonds. Therefore, it is said, Attaining the three, eliminating the three abodes.

Cultivating immeasurable mindfulness and retention means abiding in the stage of the first dhyÄna, contemplating mindfulness and retention, or in the four dhyÄnas, gathering internal and external dharmas, also having mindfulness and retention.

In the first dhyÄna, internally there is indeterminate thought, with perception and investigation, burning like fire, consuming the essence of dharmas, externally there is indeterminate thought, burned by fire.
In the second dhyÄna, internally there is indeterminate thought, the mind loves it like water, externally there is indeterminate thought, soaked by water.
In the third dhyÄna, internally there is indeterminate thought, like wind with inhalation and exhalation, externally there is indeterminate thought, moved by the wind.
In the fourth dhyÄna, internally there is no indeterminate thought, not grasped by external dharmas.
